awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021:  How spatial and temporal variation in environment and soil fungal diversity shapes plant phenotypes
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The majority of plants in temperate forests rely on interactions with soil fungi (called arbuscular mycorrhizae, AMF) to acquire important resources necessary for growth and survival. Scientific understanding of these interactions has so far been limited to relatively short-term studies, but with new advances in methodology, the field is now poised to leverage information about these relationships extracted from decades- to centuries-old museum (herbarium) specimens. In this project, the fellow will use museum specimens, combined with new field sampling, to 1) identify large spatial and temporal patterns in plant-fungi interactions; 2) link these patterns to drivers of global change; and 3) investigate how these relationships affect important plant traits linked to overall performance. Results from this work will improve our understanding of how global change affects these critical relationships, inform museums about best collection practices, and lead to the development of important educational outreach in both museum and traditional classroom settings.

To complete this work, the fellow will sequence mycorrhizal genomes from a combination of historical herbarium samples and newly collected field specimens of various Trillium species from across eastern North America. The fellow will then use hierarchical Bayesian modeling approaches to assess how climate, geographic distribution, and presence of allelopathic invaders (i.e., garlic mustard) affect AMF community composition and, consequently, how AMF composition affects important plant traits such as leaf area and foliar nitrogen content. Broader impacts resulting from this work include collaboration with museum educators and highlighting the importance of museum collections. The fellow will also develop educational outreach materials targeted for classroom and academic settings. This research will provide the fellow with new research collaborations as well as training in herbarium methodology, high-throughput genetic sequencing, invasive species modeling, and scientific communication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

My first goal for this project was to sequence the DNA of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) from herbarium specimens collected across eastern North America over the past 150 years and to quantify changes in AMF communities across space and time. I was successful in sequencing AMF DNA for 112 out of the 280 specimens (~40%) I attempted to sequence, consistent with success rates reported elsewhere in the literature. I had similar success rates across the entire temporal and geographical range explored in this study, suggesting that herbarium collections can be important reserves of genetic information for fungal species. Sequenced AMF taxa were primarily from the Glomus genus, though the genera Acaulospora, Diversispora, and Scutellospora were also successfully sequenced.

 

Initial results from my analysis suggest at least some variation in belowground communities across time and space. AMF taxon richness varied from 1-43 taxa per plant specimen out of a total of 171 AMF different taxa sequenced. AMF taxon richness tended to be higher for plant specimens that were collected more recently, but the two specimens with the highest overall AMF richness (each had nearly double the richness of the specimen with the next highest richness) were collected in 1921 and 1970. Initial PCA analysis suggests that AMF community richness and structure was similar across the three Trillium species used in this study, but that there may be a strong effect associated with the herbarium that collected the plant specimens. Since herbaria primarily collect plants from within their general geographic region, this tentatively suggests geographic partitioning of AMF community composition.

 

My second goal was to relate AMF community structure to aboveground plant traits. I did not receive permission from the herbaria I loaned specimens from to collect leaf tissue needed to measure aboveground traits such as C:N ratios. Instead, I collected Trillium specimens from the field so that I can relate mycorrhizal community structure to traits using fresh field specimens. This work is ongoing.

 

As a result of this research, I was invited to give formal research talks at the University of Michigan, the University of Tennessee, and Ewha Woman’s University in Seoul, South Korea.

 

Broader Impacts:

The main broader impact of my work is in informing herbarium collections as to the challenges and obstacles in preserving AMF DNA as part of their collections. The biggest obstacle pertains to how herbaria collect plants. Approximately 90% of the Trillium specimens I evaluated only contained aboveground tissue, meaning that no roots were collected. This dramatically reduced my potential sample size and I recommend that herbaria should focus on collecting belowground tissue when possible.

 

Second, I initiated an experiment to determine if the method with which roots were dried impacts AMF DNA sequence information. I collected Trillium in the field and dried them five different ways (air drying, silicon gel, drying oven (high heat), passive drying (low heat), and a fresh, undried control). Plants were collected in summer 2023 and DNA sequencing and analysis are ongoing.

 

I presented results from my research, including other concurrent herbarium-based projects, to public audiences in various contexts. This included invited talks to public, general audiences at the Carnegie Museum of Natural History, the Cleveland Museum of Natural History, Holden Forest and Gardens, and the Western Reserve Land Conservancy. Audiences for these talks included K12 students, gardeners clubs, land managers, and museum curators. Over 1,000 people attended my online seminar with the Western Reserve Land Conservancy. I also engaged public audiences through print and radio media including outlets such as the Pittsburgh City Paper and WESA, Pittsburgh’s local NPR station.
